title: U.S. Abortion Rate Drops to Lowest Level Since 1973
text:
The U.S. abortion rate reached its lowest levels since the procedure became legal across the country in 1973, according to a new report released Wednesday.

Both the rate and number of abortions performed in the U.S. declined nationally and in almost every state between 2014 and 2017, according to research from the Guttmacher Institute, a policy group that supports abortion rights and tracks national abortion statistics. Abortions in the U.S. have been declining for years, and researchers attribute the trend to fewer pregnancies and falling birth rates.

There were 13.5 abortions for every 1,000 women ages 15 to 44 in 2017, an 8% decline from 2014. In 1973, there were 16.3 abortions performed per 1,000 women within that same age range. The abortion rate in 2017 is also less than half of what it was in the early 1980s, according to the institute’s research.

The number of abortions has dropped in recent years, too, falling beneath 1 million in 2013 for the first time since 1974 and remaining under that threshold in subsequent years. Clinics performed around 862,320 abortions in 2017—the latest year for which data is available—marking a 7% drop since 2014 and the lowest number since 1974.

The fewest abortions on record were performed in 1973, at about 744,600, before rising to roughly 898,600 the following year and 1.03 million in 1975, according to the organization’s reports.

Abortions undertaken with medication, rather than through an in-clinic procedure, are also growing more popular among those who have terminated pregnancies. These types of methods made up 39% of all abortions in 2017 and 29% in 2014.

Research from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also shows a decline in the rate and number of abortions over the years, but its reports exclude data from a few U.S. states.

Fewer pregnancies in the U.S. were the main reason for the decline in abortions, researchers from the Guttmacher Institute said. In 2018, the number of babies born in the U.S. and the overall fertility rate hit new lows.

The report found no clear link between the declining abortion rate and new restrictions on the procedure enacted in a number of states.

“If abortion restrictions were the main driver across the board, we’d expect the birth rate to increase,” the researchers said.
